abstract.p: Footlights column reports on a premiere of Personal Equation, a 1915 play by Eugene O'Neill, a new musical called Biotech, concert by New York Pops orchestra in Prospect Park and nominations for Gotham Awards for independent filmmakers; photos (M)

block.p: Talk about a play's long journey to the stage. Ralph Waite and Daniel McDonald star in the first production of Eugene O'Neill's ''Personal Equation,'' beginning performances on Friday at the Provincetown Playhouse, 133 MacDougal Street, Greenwich Village. The play, set at the outbreak of World War I, was written in 1915, while the playwright was a Harvard student. The characters must decide whether to enlist in the army or the anarchist cause, a choice that divides a father (Mr. Waite) and son (Mr. McDonald). ''Personal Equation,'' which is at the start of the annual O'Neill festival of the Playwrights Theater of New York, has been staged by the group's artistic director, Stephen Kennedy Murphy. Information: (212) 998-5801 or www.playwrightstheater.com.

''Biotech,'' a new musical with a timely theme written and directed by Crystal Field, is this summer's street-corner production of Theater for the New City. The first of 13 free outdoor performances is scheduled for Saturday afternoon at 2 at East 10th Street and First Avenue in the East Village. The show, with music by Joseph-Vernon Banks, is a sci-fi thriller in which Alberto the gardener tries to save the world from the human spuds that have been created by a conspiracy of evil chemical conglomerates. On Sunday at 2 the production moves to Peace Place Park on 124th Street, between Second and Third Avenues in Manhattan. Performances continue on Saturday and Sunday afternoons (and on Aug. 17) in all five boroughs through Sept. 17. Information: (212) 254-1109.

Skitch Henderson will be leading the 77-member New York Pops orchestra in a concert that will begin at 7:30 on Saturday evening at the band shell in Prospect Park in Park Slope. It is part of the Celebrate Brooklyn! performing arts festival. The program is to feature the jazz vibraphonist Peter Appleyard. Information: (718) 855-7882, extension 45, or www.celebratebrooklyn.org.

The Independent Feature Project has announced the nominations for its 10th annual Gotham Awards, to be handed out on Sept. 20. The ceremony, which celebrates New York's indie filmmakers, will be shown the next night on Bravo. Nominees for the top award are Karyn Kusama's ''Girlfight,'' Tom Gilroy's ''Spring Forward,'' Bruno de Almeida's ''On the Run,'' Myles Connell's ''Opportunist,'' and Kenneth Lonegran's ''You Can Count on Me.''
